title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Activity 1: Guess 2/3rds of the average


You will each choose an integer between 0 and 100.
The winner is the person who‚Äôs guess is closest to the average of all guesses times 2/3
Submit your guess on Canvas
Backup Google forms version

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Activity 1


This is a simple example, but illustrates how complicated strategic reasoning can be.
The theoretical solution to this game says that anyone who is rational and knows that everyone else is rational (Common Knowledge of Rationality) should only choose 0 or 1.
However, Nagel, R. (1995), ‚ÄúUnravelling in guessing games : An experimental study‚Äù showed that over 12,000 answers, the average is 35.24.
Is Common Knowledge of Rationality a ‚Äòbad‚Äô assumption? How can we connect our theories with experimental evidence?




discuss different types of approaches people took
how would they revise guess 2nd time?

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Theory in a data-driven world? 1

‚ÄúThe theory of economics does not furnish a body of settled conclusions immediately applicable to policy. It is a method rather than a doctrine, an apparatus of the mind, a technique of thinking which helps its possessor to draw correct conclusions.‚Äù ‚Äî Keynes

adapted from Glen Waddell‚Äôs microeconometrics class

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Why is theory useful?

helps us simplify and understand complex systems

Social systems are really hard, game theory helps us focus on small parts at a time

lets us generate falsifiable & testable hypotheses

Good econometrics is informed by good theory

gives us common ground to analyze important questions

How can we focus on the details that really matter?




Use map example:
World Atlas or UOCampus Map?
Which is better depends on which is more useful

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: What are the limits to theory?
text:
What are the limits to theory?


Our models will never be perfect representations of reality
But we should know how well they approximate the parts of the world we want to understand
Theory is very useful for generating falsifiable hypotheses, which we can then use to guide experimental or statistical tests
As we play games in class, we will observe the data and compare to our theoretical predictions

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Examples of some questions:


When should the Ducks play a running play or passing play?
Why is a pdf textbook so expensive?!
Why did the US and USSR adopt Mutually Assured Destruction?
Why do people give engagement rings?

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: What do all these questions have in common?
text:
What do all these questions have in common?


They all involve people making choices which depend on the choices of others
In other words, they are questions of strategy:

Strategic interdependence is present in a social situation when what is best for someone depends on what someone else does. 1



Harrington, pg. 2

title: Introduction to Game Theory
Introduction to Game Theory
text:
What defines a player?

Preferences: Everyone has certain things they want.
But you usually can‚Äôt get everything you want; economics is all about constrained choices.
So its important to have priorities and to understand which things people prefer to others.
Information: Some people might be better informed than others.
Beliefs: What do I think about when I have to make a strategic choice?

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Preferences
Preferences describe the subjective ranking that we put on different alternatives.
For example, on the set of Eugene boba stores, my preference ranking goes like this;


Day & Night - they have mango sago, cute location
Tea 4 - major chain, good quality and selection
Bobahead - no more campus location üòî
No boba
Rabbit Hole - no hate, just not for me

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Rational Preferences
The rational model of choice is the foundation of all economics.
Its assumptions are that:


People have complete preferences

for every pair of options, you can either tell me which you prefer or that you are indifferent
for any pair of deserts, \(\{ \ üç® \ , \ üç© \ \}\), either \((üç® \succ üç© \ )\), or \((üç© \ \succ üç® \ )\), or \((üç® \sim üç© \ )\)

Preferences are transitive

if \((‚òï \succ üçµ \ )\) and \((üçµ \succ üç∂ \ )\), then \((‚òï \succ üç∂)\) ( for any \(\{‚òï \ , üçµ \ , üç∂ \ \} \in ü´ñ \ \))

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Rational Preferences (cont.)
Another key assumption of rationality is that we can represent preferences by real numbers.
A utility function maps a choice to a single number.
For example, let \(u(.)\) be the utility function from emoji to utils

I can have \(u(üç∫) =5\), \(u(üåØ)=10\), \(u(ü§∏)=25\)
I can also have \(u(üç∫ \ , üåØ) = 20\), \(u(üç∫ \ , üåØ \ , ü§∏) = 15\)

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Ordinal vs.¬†Cardinal numbers


Cardinal: amounts which can be measured in meaningful units are cardinal numbers

examples: $9.99, 80 students, 50:50 odds

Ordinal: all that matters is the relative ranking

examples: utility; what does 100 utility mean? (it‚Äôs less than 200)

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Don‚Äôt worry!


For this class, you won‚Äôt need to worry about utility functions (if you want to, take EC311).
I will almost always give you specific values of utility which we will call payoffs.
The table on the previous page is a good example.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: Strategic Choice vs.¬†other types of choices
text:
Strategic Choice vs.¬†other types of choices


Economics is the study of constrained choice; in EC311, we introduce the utility maximization problem as the workhorse model

These types of problems usually only involve one agent; the consumer, who is only constrained by their budget

We use the term strategic games to distinguish from these single-agent optimization problems
A game is a type of problem featuring multiple agents, called players, in which their optimal choice depends on the optimal choices of other players.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
State-dependent utility table


Sometimes my enjoyment of a thing depends on the state of the world


socially-dependent preferences


My choice
My friends‚Äô choice

Is this an example of a strategic or non-strategic choice?

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
General Categories

Sequential or Simultaneous?
Zero-sum or not
Perfect or Imperfect information?

is info symmetric or asymmetric?

One-shot or Repeated?
‚ÄòNoncooperative‚Äô or ‚ÄòCooperative‚Äô?

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Sequential Games

players make their moves one after the other
Chapter 3
Visual tool: game trees
Solution Method: backwards induction


Simultaneous Games

players make their moves at the same time
Chapter 4 & 5
Visual tool: payoff tables
Solution Method: best responses, deletion of dominated strats

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Zero-sum games

When the total payoffs of all players sum to 0

i.e, one player‚Äôs gain is another player‚Äôs loss
Examples: NCAA Football Championship, Scramble for Africa (technically constant-sum)

Not all games are fixed or zero sum;

Examples: Hiring a tutor (mutual gains), Wargames (1983) ‚Äúthe only winning move is not to play‚Äù

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Full or Equal Information
How much does each player know when they decide?


Perfect Information: when players know all previous moves and external circumstances

players may have imperfect info; uncertainty about the state of the world, previous‚Äô moves, or other player‚Äôs ‚Äòtype‚Äô

Asymmetric Info: when one player has access to information that other players do not

Examples: hand in poker, used car salesmen
Topics: Signaling, Screening

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: The Battle of Wits (The Princess Bride - 1987)
text:
The Battle of Wits (The Princess Bride - 1987)

The ‚ÄúMan in Black‚Äù and Vizzini agree to a battle of wits to break the impasse.
Vizzini claims that his own brain puts Plato, Aristotle, and Socrates to shame and demonstrates his recursive strategic reasoning.

Good pitching will always stop good hitting and vice-versa. -Casey Stengel

Harrington, pg 21

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Baseball, I 1

It is the bottom of the ninth inning, and the game is tied between the Orioles and the Yankees. The pitcher on the mound for the Yankees is Masahiro Tanaka, who is a right-hander, and the batter due up for the Orioles is Adam Jones, who is also a right-hander. The Orioles‚Äô manager is thinking about whether to substitute Chris Davis, who is a left-handed batter, for Jones. He would prefer to have Davis face Tanaka in order to have a lefty‚Äìrighty matchup and thus a better chance of getting a hit. However, the Yankees‚Äô manager could respond to Davis‚Äô pinch-hitting by substituting the left-handed pitcher Cesar Cabral for Tanaka. The Orioles‚Äô manager would rather have Jones face Tanaka than have Davis face Cabral. Of course, the Yankees‚Äô manager has the exact opposite preferences.

Harrington, pg 21

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Split Into Groups

library(tidyverse)

names <- read_csv("EC327names.csv") %>% select(First, Last)
n = nrow(names)
group_size = 4
num_groups = round(n/4)

# set seed to make group selection consistent across sessions
set.seed(2024)
# assign groups and make a table
names %>%
  mutate(Group = sample(1:num_groups, n, replace = TRUE)) %>%
  group_by(Group) %>%
  summarise(names = list((First))) %>%
  pivot_wider(names_from = Group, values_from = names) %>%
  knitr::kable()

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Set Up


Find an opposing group
Pick someone to record flags for each round
Draw 21 flags on whiteboard
Discuss strategy w/ your group for 1 minute
Play the game!

Don‚Äôt forget to record how many flags each round!!!

title: EC327 Game Theory
section: Modified Rules: choose number of flags to start
text:
Modified Rules: choose number of flags to start
Find a new team to play against (losers move)


This time, one team will choose the number of starting flags: between 15-25
The other team will choose whether to allow max. of 2-5 flags per round
Play and record!

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Discuss
In your teams briefly discuss the following:

Is there a correct way to play the game?
How did you find out the best way to play the game?
Is the game solved meaning that the winner can be correctly predicted from any point in the game? If so, should the first or second team always win?
Were there more errors in the first games played than the last games played? Why?
How was this game different from the guessing 2/3rds game?

text:

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Recap

There is a correct way to play: we will later call the Nash equilibrium
You likely used some form of backwards induction or rollback reasoning
This game was sequential unlike the simultaneous 2/3rds game

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Prerequisites

Courses: EC201 or EC202
Knowledge: This class will require you to use some simple algebra and graphing skills. If you felt uncomfortable with the level of math in EC201, I recommend that you review how to solve simple systems of equations, inequalities, and fractions.

There are great free resources out there like Khan Academy, but always feel free to reach out for help or other suggestions.

Come to class

Pay attention to lectures, take notes, review topics at home
Participate in group work & activities
Ask questions!

Communicate respectfully

With your classmates
With me & grader

Have academic integrity 1

Verify that all submitted work is your own
Provide sources for all information that you found outside this class

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Problem Sets
You will practice what we learn in class on independently.
Each homework assignment will be a few problems that will be similar to what you will see on exams.


Learning something new takes practice, so these are designed to help you keep up with the concepts
You will be graded not only on whether you got a certain answer, but also more importantly on how you communicate your understanding

See Canvas rubric for more info

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Class Activities
You will break into groups to work collaboratively on different activities


Sometimes I will ask you to play the types of games we discuss in lectures

Record the strategies you chose and the outcomes
Reflect on how you played the game
Relate it to lecture concepts





I‚Äôm still working out how best to implement
this is how you participate, records attendance on activity days
hopefully lets you experience first-had the things we learn

You will demonstrate how well you understand concepts individually on a midterm and a final exam

sometime around week 5 (Oct.¬†28th or 30th)

Final

finals week of December 9 (check duckweb for specific date)
Covers everything we learned in the quarter, with more focus on concepts from the 2nd half

expect exams to be difficult
Best way to prepare is lots of practice

EC327 | Lecture 0| Syllabus

title: Nash Equilibrium
text:
Before we cover how to solve a game, we first need to discuss what a solution to a game even is.
As with many types of problem in economics, we‚Äôre interested in finding an equilibrium:

equilibrium a situation which is ‚Äústable,‚Äù in that there is no incentive to change.






The most basic form of equilibrium in game theory is the Nash Equilibrium (NE), which can be described as:

A strategy profile such that no player can obtain a larger payoff by unilaterally deviating
A strategy profile such that no single player can make themselves better off by changing only their own strategy.
A strategy profile such that, after the game is played, each player is satisfied that they could not have made a better decision





Two criminal conspirators have been arrested and brought to interrogation. The police put them in separate cells and offer each prisoner a choice.
If both cooperate with the investigation, they will get a lighter sentence of 10 years.
If either one agrees to testify but not the other, the one who cooperated will go free and the one who didn‚Äôt gets a full 20 years.
If neither cooperates, the prosecutor won‚Äôt have enough of a case and the criminals will only serve 1 year each for misdemeanors.





Remember that you cannot communicate with your fellow prisoner
How would you have to be that they won‚Äôt sell you out for you to choose to keep quiet?





Although the outcome where both criminals keep quiet Pareto dominates the outcome where they both testify and serve 10 years, would it be stable?

In the {Quiet, Quiet} strategy profile, either player could deviate to Testify and shorten their prison time.
{Testify, Testify} is the only stable strategy profile, where no one could unilaterally deviate to decrease their sentence.













Split
Steal




Split
\((\$6,800, \$6,800)\)
\((\$0, 13,600)\)


Steal
\((\$13,600, \$0)\)
\((\$0, \$0)\)



Although the numbers are different, the structure is the same.
Split or Steal is a Prisoners‚Äô Dilemma





start from 2:20





Did Nick change the structure of the game?

title: Nash Equilibrium
text: Did Nick change the structure of the game?

title: Backwards Induction
text:
figures/fig3.2.png









figures/fig3.3.png









figures/fig3.4.png









figures/fig3.5.png






The method of looking at decisions in the future to decide what to do now is called Backwards Induction or Rollback






Definition 1



When all players do rollback analysis to choose their optimal strategies, we call this set of strategies the rollback equilibrium2 of the game; the outcome that arises from playing these strategies is the rollback equilibrium outcome






Consider the Flag game but instead of starting with 21 flags the game starts with 5 flags, and instead of being able to pick 1,2, or 3 flags teams can only pick 1 or 2 flags.

Draw the extensive form game tree complete with all payoff for both teams.
How many total strategies are there for team 1?
Use pruning to eliminate actions to get to a rollback equilibrium. Who will win? What is the winning strategy?





We can start to add more complexity with more than two players






Emily, Nina, and Talia are roommates who want to get a start on their communal garden.
They like to enjoy the benefits of fresh produce and green space, but it is costly for them to put the work in.
2 or 3 people working is enough to keep the garden healthy, but if 1 or 0 work, then the garden will die.









outcome:
utlity:




I don‚Äôt contribute, but garden lives
4


I contribute, and get garden.
3


I don‚Äôt contribute, and garden dies
2


I contribute, but garden dies
1










figures/fig3.6.png







Note that there is one continuous path we traced from the initial node to a final equilibrium outcome.
However, we couldn‚Äôt have gotten their without the other arrows paths even though they are never reached in equilibrium.
Recall that a strategy is a collection of choices at every decision node.





Even though the players available actions are all called the same (Contribute or Don‚Äôt), this tree provides labels of each decision node so we can say something like:

‚ÄúNina‚Äôs strategy in the rollback equilibrium is { Don‚Äôt Contribute at b, Contribute at c }‚Äù.


To make it even shorter, let‚Äôs call this strategy DC.







CCCC, CCCD, CCDC, CCDD, CDCC, CDCD, CDDC, CDDD, DCCC, DCCD, DCDC, DCDD, DDCC, DDCD, DDDC, DDDD
16 total strategies






The equilibrium is:

{ D3, DC4, DCCD5 }





Even a simple game get complicated fast










Even though it looks complicated, the main branches are really just copies of each other
Most people probably figure out the rollback equilibrium after playing it enough
Insert relevant xkcd here: https://xkcd.com/832/






What about more complicated games like chess?

technically rollback solvable, but with \(10^{120}\) possible moves, it hasn‚Äôt been solved by either human or machine

Players of complicated sequential games often implement some intermediate valuation function to assign payoffs to non-terminal nodes.

title: Welfare and Efficiency
text:
What are the good outcomes in the planting game?
Can we rank outcomes by collective welfare?





Pareto optimality (or efficiency) is econonomists‚Äô best shot at coming up with a ranking of which outcomes are objectively ‚Äòbetter‚Äô

For any two outcomes (üéâ, üéä), üéâ is Pareto dominated by üéä if both:

No one strictly prefers üéâ to üéä - Uüë§(üéä) \(\geq\) Uüë§(üéâ) \(\forall üë§ \in \{ üôç, üßë, üíÜ, üßñ, üßë, üò∫, ...\}\)
At least one person strictlyüéâ prefers üéâ to üéä - \(\exists üë§\) such that Uüë§(üéä) \(>\) Uüë§(üéâ)






The move from a policy y to an alternative policy x is a Pareto improvement if x Pareto dominates y.

Such a policy change should reasonably be seen as unambiguously good
Another perspective is that no-one would veto a pareto improvement





An outcome is Pareto Efficient (Optimal) if no other outcome Pareto dominates it.
An outcome is Pareto Infficient if at least one other outcome Pareto dominates it.




Compare (4,3,3) to (1,2,2)

Which one is Pareto dominating?





Now compare (4,3,3) to (3,4,3) or (3,3,4)

Which one is Pareto dominating?

Is the rollback equilibrium outcome a Pareto efficient one?






How useful is Pareto Efficiency in the real world?
How else could we group outcomes?
We might address this later in the class with what is known as Cooperative Game Theory

title: What is Theory?
text:
‚ÄúThe theory of economics does not furnish a body of settled conclusions immediately applicable to policy. It is a method rather than a doctrine, an apparatus of the mind, a technique of thinking which helps its possessor to draw correct conclusions.‚Äù ‚Äî Keynes





helps us simplify and understand complex systems

Social systems are really hard, game theory helps us focus on small parts at a time

lets us generate falsifiable & testable hypotheses

Good econometrics is informed by good theory

gives us common ground to analyze important questions

How can we focus on the details that really matter?




Use map example:
World Atlas or UOCampus Map?
Which is better depends on which is more useful








Our models will never be perfect representations of reality
But we should know how well they approximate the parts of the world we want to understand
Theory is very useful for generating falsifiable hypotheses, which we can then use to guide experimental or statistical tests
As we play games in class, we will observe the data and compare to our theoretical predictions

title: Topics:
text:
Basic Toolkit:
- Simultaneous Games 
    - Strategic Form Tables
    - Pure Strategies
        - Eliminating Strictly Dominated Strategies
        - Identifying Best Responses
        - Pure Strategy Nash Equilibria
    - Mixed Strategies
        - Defining a mixed strategy 
        - solving for indifference conditions
- Sequential Games
    - Extensive Form Trees
        - Subgames
        - Information Sets
    - Subgame-Perfect Nash Equilibria
    - Backwards Induction
- Expected Utility
    - Risk averse vs risk seeking
- Present Value
Applications and Topics:
- Uncertainty
    - Asymmetric Info
        - Pooling vs Separating eq
        - Cheap Talk
            - Babbling eq
        - Signalling
        - Screening
            - Mechanism Design 
                - Incentive Compatible 
                - Individually Rational
        - Adverse Selection
            - Examples: Insurance, Used cars 
            - Solutions: Reputation, warranty, etc
    - Symmetric uncertainty
- Strategic Moves
    - Commitments, Threats, and Promises
    - Credibility
    - Brinksmanship
        - Strategic randomized plays
    - Examples: Market Entry games, Game of Chicken, Cuban Missile Crisis
- Repeated Games
    - Infinite Horizon Payoffs
    - Strategies:
        - Grim Trigger 
        - Tit-for-Tat
    - Solving for discount factors which support cooperation
Other Related Concepts:
- Pareto Efficiency/Optimality, Pareto Dominance
- Revealed Preference 
- Hypothesis Testing (Chi-sq)

title: What is a Game? Definitions
What is a Game? Definitions
text:
When should the Ducks play a running play or passing play?
Why is a pdf textbook so expensive?!
Why did the US and USSR adopt Mutually Assured Destruction?
Why do people give engagement rings?

title: What is a Game? Definitions
text:
They all involve people making choices which depend on the choices of others
In other words, they are questions of strategy:

Strategic interdependence is present in a social situation when what is best for someone depends on what someone else does. 1

title: What is a Game? Definitions
What is a Game? Definitions
text:
What defines a player?

Preferences: Everyone has certain things they want.
But you usually can‚Äôt get everything you want; economics is all about constrained choices.
So its important to have priorities and to understand which things people prefer to others.
Information: Some people might be better informed than others.
Beliefs: What do I think about when I have to make a strategic choice?

title: What is a Game? Definitions
text:
Preferences
Preferences describe the subjective ranking that we put on different alternatives.
For example, on the set of Eugene boba stores, my preference ranking goes like this;


Day & Night - they have mango sago, cute location
Tea 4 - major chain, good quality and selection
Bobahead - no more campus location üòî
No boba
Rabbit Hole - no hate, just not for me

title: What is a Game? Definitions
text:
Rational Preferences
The rational model of choice is the foundation of all economics.
Its assumptions are that:


People have complete preferences

for every pair of options, you can either tell me which you prefer or that you are indifferent
for any pair of deserts, \(\{ \ üç® \ , \ üç© \ \}\), either \((üç® \succ üç© \ )\), or \((üç© \ \succ üç® \ )\), or \((üç® \sim üç© \ )\)

Preferences are transitive

if \((‚òï \succ üçµ \ )\) and \((üçµ \succ üç∂ \ )\), then \((‚òï \succ üç∂)\) ( for any \(\{‚òï \ , üçµ \ , üç∂ \ \} \in ü´ñ \ \))

title: What is a Game? Definitions
text:
Rational Preferences (cont.)
Another key assumption of rationality is that we can represent preferences by real numbers.
A utility function maps a choice to a single number.
For example, let \(u(.)\) be the utility function from emoji to utils

I can have \(u(üç∫) =5\), \(u(üåØ)=10\), \(u(ü§∏)=25\)
I can also have \(u(üç∫ \ , üåØ) = 20\), \(u(üç∫ \ , üåØ \ , ü§∏) = 15\)

title: What is a Game? Definitions
text:
Ordinal vs.¬†Cardinal numbers


Cardinal: amounts which can be measured in meaningful units are cardinal numbers

examples: $9.99, 80 students, 50:50 odds

Ordinal: all that matters is the relative ranking

examples: utility; what does 100 utility mean? (it‚Äôs less than 200)

title: What is a Game? Definitions
text:
Don‚Äôt worry!


For this class, you won‚Äôt need to worry about utility functions (if you want to, take EC311).
I will almost always give you specific values of utility which we will call payoffs.
The table on the previous page is a good example.

title: What is a Game? Definitions
section: Strategic Choice vs.¬†other types of choices
text:
Strategic Choice vs.¬†other types of choices


Economics is the study of constrained choice; in EC311, we introduce the utility maximization problem as the workhorse model

These types of problems usually only involve one agent; the consumer, who is only constrained by their budget

We use the term strategic games to distinguish from these single-agent optimization problems
A game is a type of problem featuring multiple agents, called players, in which their optimal choice depends on the optimal choices of other players.

title: What is a Game? Definitions
text:
State-dependent utility table


Sometimes my enjoyment of a thing depends on the state of the world


socially-dependent preferences


My choice
My friends‚Äô choice
My utility




Duck‚Äôs game
Duck‚Äôs game
3


Duck‚Äôs game
Stay home
2


Stay home
Duck‚Äôs game
1


Stay home
Stay home
2




Is this an example of a strategic or non-strategic choice?

title: What is a Game? Definitions
text:
General Categories

Sequential or Simultaneous?
Zero-sum or not
Perfect or Imperfect information?

is info symmetric or asymmetric?

One-shot or Repeated?
‚ÄòNoncooperative‚Äô or ‚ÄòCooperative‚Äô?

title: What is a Game? Definitions
text:
Sequential Games

players make their moves one after the other
Chapter 3
Visual tool: game trees
Solution Method: backwards induction


Simultaneous Games

players make their moves at the same time
Chapter 4 & 5
Visual tool: payoff tables
Solution Method: best responses, deletion of dominated strats

title: What is a Game? Definitions
text:
Zero-sum games

When the total payoffs of all players sum to 0

i.e, one player‚Äôs gain is another player‚Äôs loss
Examples: NCAA Football Championship, Scramble for Africa (technically constant-sum)

Not all games are fixed or zero sum;

Examples: Hiring a tutor (mutual gains), Wargames (1983) ‚Äúthe only winning move is not to play‚Äù

title: What is a Game? Definitions
text:
Full or Equal Information
How much does each player know when they decide?


Perfect Information: when players know all previous moves and external circumstances

players may have imperfect info; uncertainty about the state of the world, previous‚Äô moves, or other player‚Äôs ‚Äòtype‚Äô

Asymmetric Info: when one player has access to information that other players do not

Examples: hand in poker, used car salesmen
Topics: Signaling, Screening

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Activity 1


This is a simple example, but illustrates how complicated strategic reasoning can be.
The theoretical solution to this game says that anyone who is rational and knows that everyone else is rational (Common Knowledge of Rationality) should only choose 0 or 1.
However, Nagel, R. (1995), ‚ÄúUnravelling in guessing games : An experimental study‚Äù showed that over 12,000 answers, the average is 35.24.
Is Common Knowledge of Rationality a ‚Äòbad‚Äô assumption? How can we connect our theories with experimental evidence?




discuss different types of approaches people took
how would they revise guess 2nd time?

title: Extensive Form
text:
Before we learn how to solve a game, it will helpful to be able to visualize them
Because of the ordered nature of sequential games, a tree diagram makes sense











Is this a strategic decision?






A Tree Graph consists of:

Multiple nodes with an ordered hierarchy starting from one initial node
Branches coming from each node which connect it to later nodes
The tree ends in any of the multiple terminal nodes







Warning



Each (non-initial) terminal node may have multiple branches leading from it; but must only have one branch that leads to it.


































A kidnapper named Guy has contacted the victim‚Äôs wife, named Vivica, to demand a ransom.
To predict what will happen to the victim, Orlando, we need to create a game theoretic model of the situation.
Let‚Äôs use the language of the tree graph to visualize this game.















Who are the players?
Where are the decisions?
What are the branches? What do they represent?
What do the terminal nodes represent?
Is this a complete representation of a game? What‚Äôs missing?














Outcome
Guy
Vivica




No kidnapping
3
5


Kidnapping, ransom paid, Orlando killed
4
1


Kidnapping, ransom paid, Orlando released
5
3


Kidnapping, no ransom paid, Orlando killed
2
2


Kidnapping, no ransom paid, Orlando released
1
4
















Based on the extensive form game tree with payoffs, do you have any predictions for what strategies each player will choose?





A collection of decision-makers, called players or agents
A set of decision nodes, each of which represents the information available to the player of that node
Branches from each node which represent the possible actions available to the players
The entire game tree serves as the mapping from intersections of players‚Äô strategy profiles to the outcomes at each terminal nodes












Definition 3



A strategy for a player in a perfect-information game is a list of choices, one for each decision node of that player.








Warning



Be careful to distinguish between a strategy and a single action/choice


What‚Äôs the difference?






How many choices does Guy make?


3


Vivica?


1


Write out a strategy list for each player:






Guy:

{Kidnap, Kill if ransom paid, Don‚Äôt Kill if no ransom paid} is one strategy

Guy has \(8\) total strategies:
{Kidnap, Kill, Kill}, {Kidnap, Kill, Don‚Äôt}, {Kidnap, Don‚Äôt, Kill}, {Kidnap, Don‚Äôt, Don‚Äôt}, {No Kidnap, Kill, Kill}, {No Kidnap, Kill, Don‚Äôt}, {No Kidnap, Kill, Kill}, {Kidnap, Don‚Äôt, Kill}


Vivica:

Only two strategies: {Pay the ransom}, or {Don‚Äôt pay}






One way to represent risk or uncertainty is to represent Nature as a ‚Äòplayer‚Äô.

title: Strategic Form
text:
https://youtu.be/S0qjK3TWZE8
Pause at 2:20. We‚Äôll come back to Nick and Ibrahim!




From the perspective of Nick, his payoffs depend on what Ibrahim has chosen:




if Ibrahim Splits
if Ibrahim Steals




if Nick Splits he wins:
\(\$6,800\)
\(\$ 0\)


if Nick Steals he wins:
\(\$13,600\)
\(\$ 0\)







From the perspective of Ibrahim, his payoffs depend on what Nick has chosen:




if Nick Splits
if Nick Steals




if Ibrahim Splits he wins:
\(\$6,800\)
\(\$ 0\)


if Ibrahim Steals he wins:
\(\$13,600\)
\(\$ 0\)







In a game, the best choices are interdependent:








(Nick: \(\$x\), Ibrahim: \(\$y\))
Ibrahim Splits
Ibrahim Steals




Nick Splits
\((\$6,800, \$6,800)\)
\((\$0, 13,600)\)


Nick Steals
\((\$13,600, \$0)\)
\((\$0, \$0)\)






A Strategic Form game is defined by:

A set of players who have decisions
A strategy set for each player which is the collection of strategies they choose from
A payoff function which tells us how the player evaluates a strategy profile.







Tip



A strategy profile is a combination of strategies made by all players.







Each player‚Äôs strategy set has two strategies, each of one choice: Split \(Sp\) or Steal \(St\).
There are four different strategy profiles possible in this game:

\(\{Sp, Sp\}\), \(\{Sp, St\}\), \(\{St, Sp\}\), and \(\{St, St\}\)
each of which was represented by a cell in our game table.

text:

title: Strategic Form
text:
Each player‚Äôs strategy set has two strategies, each of one choice: Split \(Sp\) or Steal \(St\).
There are four different strategy profiles possible in this game:

\(\{Sp, Sp\}\), \(\{Sp, St\}\), \(\{St, Sp\}\), and \(\{St, St\}\)
each of which was represented by a cell in our game table.

title: Examples
text:
The ‚ÄúMan in Black‚Äù and Vizzini agree to a battle of wits to break the impasse.
Vizzini claims that his own brain puts Plato, Aristotle, and Socrates to shame and demonstrates his recursive strategic reasoning.






Good pitching will always stop good hitting and vice-versa. -Casey Stengel




Batter
Pitcher
Batting Average




\(Right\)
\(Left\)
.255


\(Right\)
\(Left\)
.274


\(Left\)
\(Right\)
.291


\(Left\)
\(Left\)
.266




Rank each player‚Äôs preferences over strategy profile intersections






It is the bottom of the ninth inning, and the game is tied between the Orioles and the Yankees. The pitcher on the mound for the Yankees is Masahiro Tanaka, who is a right-hander, and the batter due up for the Orioles is Adam Jones, who is also a right-hander. The Orioles‚Äô manager is thinking about whether to substitute Chris Davis, who is a left-handed batter, for Jones. He would prefer to have Davis face Tanaka in order to have a lefty‚Äìrighty matchup and thus a better chance of getting a hit. However, the Yankees‚Äô manager could respond to Davis‚Äô pinch-hitting by substituting the left-handed pitcher Cesar Cabral for Tanaka. The Orioles‚Äô manager would rather have Jones face Tanaka than have Davis face Cabral. Of course, the Yankees‚Äô manager has the exact opposite preferences.






Draw the extensive form of this situation:

title: Examples
text: It is the bottom of the ninth inning, and the game is tied between the Orioles and the Yankees. The pitcher on the mound for the Yankees is Masahiro Tanaka, who is a right-hander, and the batter due up for the Orioles is Adam Jones, who is also a right-hander. The Orioles‚Äô manager is thinking about whether to substitute Chris Davis, who is a left-handed batter, for Jones. He would prefer to have Davis face Tanaka in order to have a lefty‚Äìrighty matchup and thus a better chance of getting a hit. However, the Yankees‚Äô manager could respond to Davis‚Äô pinch-hitting by substituting the left-handed pitcher Cesar Cabral for Tanaka. The Orioles‚Äô manager would rather have Jones face Tanaka than have Davis face Cabral. Of course, the Yankees‚Äô manager has the exact opposite preferences.

text: Draw the extensive form of this situation:

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
The Strategic Form
A Strategic Form game is defined by:

A set of players who have decisions
A strategy set for each player which is the collection of strategies they choose from
A payoff function which tells us how the player evaluates a strategy profile.







Tip


A strategy profile is a combination of strategies made by all players.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: Strategy profiles in Split or Steal
text:
Strategy profiles in Split or Steal

Each player‚Äôs strategy set has two strategies, each of one choice: Split \(Sp\) or Steal \(St\).
There are four different strategy profiles possible in this game:

\(\{Sp, Sp\}\), \(\{Sp, St\}\), \(\{St, Sp\}\), and \(\{St, St\}\)
each of which was represented by a cell in our game table.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Solving Simultaneous Games

Before we cover how to solve a game, we first need to discuss what a solution to a game even is.
As with many types of problem in economics, we‚Äôre interested in finding an equilibrium:

equilibrium a situation which is ‚Äústable,‚Äù in that there is no incentive to change.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Nash Equilibrium
The most basic form of equilibrium in game theory is the Nash Equilibrium (NE), which can be described as:

A strategy profile such that no player can obtain a larger payoff by unilaterally deviating
A strategy profile such that no single player can make themselves better off by changing only their own strategy.
A strategy profile such that, after the game is played, each player is satisfied that they could not have made a better decision

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
The Prisoner‚Äôs Dilemma
Two criminal conspirators have been arrested and brought to interrogation. The police put them in separate cells and offer each prisoner a choice.
If both cooperate with the investigation, they will get a lighter sentence of 10 years.
If either one agrees to testify but not the other, the one who cooperated will go free and the one who didn‚Äôt gets a full 20 years.
If neither cooperates, the prosecutor won‚Äôt have enough of a case and the criminals will only serve 1 year each for misdemeanors.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
What would you choose?

Remember that you cannot communicate with your fellow prisoner
How would you have to be that they won‚Äôt sell you out for you to choose to keep quiet?

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: Nash Equilibrium in the Prisoners‚Äô Dilemma
text:
Nash Equilibrium in the Prisoners‚Äô Dilemma
Although the outcome where both criminals keep quiet Pareto dominates the outcome where they both testify and serve 10 years, would it be stable?

In the {Quiet, Quiet} strategy profile, either player could deviate to Testify and shorten their prison time.
{Testify, Testify} is the only stable strategy profile, where no one could unilaterally deviate to decrease their sentence.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: Draw Prisoners‚Äô Dilemma in Strategic Form:
text: Draw Prisoners‚Äô Dilemma in Strategic Form:

text:

\((\$0, \$0)\)



Although the numbers are different, the structure is the same.
Split or Steal is a Prisoners‚Äô Dilemma

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: Game Trees/Extensive Form as a tool
text:
Game Trees/Extensive Form as a tool

Before we learn how to solve a game, it will helpful to be able to visualize them
Because of the ordered nature of sequential games, a tree diagram makes sense

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
A Decision Tree


Is this a strategic decision?

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Extensive Form Definition

A Tree Graph consists of:

Multiple nodes with an ordered hierarchy starting from one initial node
Branches coming from each node which connect it to later nodes
The tree ends in any of the multiple terminal nodes







Warning


Each (non-initial) terminal node may have multiple branches leading from it; but must only have one branch that leads to it.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text: Anatomy of a tree

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Kidnapping Game 1
A kidnapper named Guy has contacted the victim‚Äôs wife, named Vivica, to demand a ransom.
To predict what will happen to the victim, Orlando, we need to create a game theoretic model of the situation.
Let‚Äôs use the language of the tree graph to visualize this game.
Harrington, pg 18

text:

Who are the players?
Where are the decisions?
What are the branches? What do they represent?

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Predictions?
Based on the extensive form game tree with payoffs, do you have any predictions for what strategies each player will choose?

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: a Definition of an Extensive Form Game: 1
text:
a Definition of an Extensive Form Game: 1

A collection of decision-makers, called players or agents
A set of decision nodes, each of which represents the information available to the player of that node
Branches from each node which represent the possible actions available to the players
The entire game tree serves as the mapping from intersections of players‚Äô strategy profiles to the outcomes at each terminal nodes

for finite, perfect information games

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Strategies in Extensive Form Games







Definition 1


A strategy for a player in a perfect-information game is a list of choices, one for each decision node of that player.









Warning


Be careful to distinguish between a strategy and a single action/choice



What‚Äôs the difference?

Bonanno, pg 83

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: Apply this definition to the kidnapping game:
text:
Apply this definition to the kidnapping game:

How many choices does Guy make?


3


Vivica?


1


Write out a strategy list for each player:

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: Write out a strategy for each player
text:
Write out a strategy for each player

Guy:

{Kidnap, Kill if ransom paid, Don‚Äôt Kill if no ransom paid} is one strategy

Guy has \(8\) total strategies:
{Kidnap, Kill, Kill}, {Kidnap, Kill, Don‚Äôt}, {Kidnap, Don‚Äôt, Kill}, {Kidnap, Don‚Äôt, Don‚Äôt}, {No Kidnap, Kill, Kill}, {No Kidnap, Kill, Don‚Äôt}, {No Kidnap, Kill, Kill}, {Kidnap, Don‚Äôt, Kill}


Vivica:

Only two strategies: {Pay the ransom}, or {Don‚Äôt pay}

Letting Nature take the wheel

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Backwards Induction defined
The method of looking at decisions in the future to decide what to do now is called Backwards Induction or Rollback






Definition 1


When all players do rollback analysis to choose their optimal strategies, we call this set of strategies the rollback equilibrium2 of the game; the outcome that arises from playing these strategies is the rollback equilibrium outcome



Dixit et al, pg 56aka subgame perfect equilibrium

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Group Exercise:
Consider the Flag game but instead of starting with 21 flags the game starts with 5 flags, and instead of being able to pick 1,2, or 3 flags teams can only pick 1 or 2 flags.

Draw the extensive form game tree complete with all payoff for both teams.
How many total strategies are there for team 1?
Use pruning to eliminate actions to get to a rollback equilibrium. Who will win? What is the winning strategy?

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Adding more players
We can start to add more complexity with more than two players

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
3-player planting game


Emily, Nina, and Talia are roommates who want to get a start on their communal garden.
They like to enjoy the benefits of fresh produce and green space, but it is costly for them to put the work in.
2 or 3 people working is enough to keep the garden healthy, but if 1 or 0 work, then the garden will die.

Planding Game Tree

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Equilibrium Path of Play

Note that there is one continuous path we traced from the initial node to a final equilibrium outcome.
However, we couldn‚Äôt have gotten their without the other arrows paths even though they are never reached in equilibrium.
Recall that a strategy is a collection of choices at every decision node.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Equilibrium Strategies
Even though the players available actions are all called the same (Contribute or Don‚Äôt), this tree provides labels of each decision node so we can say something like:

‚ÄúNina‚Äôs strategy in the rollback equilibrium is { Don‚Äôt Contribute at b, Contribute at c }‚Äù.


To make it even shorter, let‚Äôs call this strategy DC.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: How many strategies does Talia have?
text:
How many strategies does Talia have?


CCCC, CCCD, CCDC, CCDD, CDCC, CDCD, CDDC, CDDD, DCCC, DCCD, DCDC, DCDD, DDCC, DDCD, DDDC, DDDD
16 total strategies

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:

The equilibrium is:

{ D1, DC2, DCCD3 }

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Adding More Moves
Even a simple game get complicated fast

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Tic-Tac-Toe

Even though it looks complicated, the main branches are really just copies of each other
Most people probably figure out the rollback equilibrium after playing it enough
Insert relevant xkcd here: https://xkcd.com/832/

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Chess

What about more complicated games like chess?

technically rollback solvable, but with \(10^{120}\) possible moves, it hasn‚Äôt been solved by either human or machine

Players of complicated sequential games often implement some intermediate valuation function to assign payoffs to non-terminal nodes.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Pareto Dominance
Pareto optimality (or efficiency) is econonomists‚Äô best shot at coming up with a ranking of which outcomes are objectively ‚Äòbetter‚Äô

For any two outcomes (üéâ, üéä), üéâ is Pareto dominated by üéä if both:

No one strictly prefers üéâ to üéä - Uüë§(üéä) \(\geq\) Uüë§(üéâ) \(\forall üë§ \in \{ üôç, üßë, üíÜ, üßñ, üßë, üò∫, ...\}\)
At least one person strictlyüéâ prefers üéâ to üéä - \(\exists üë§\) such that Uüë§(üéä) \(>\) Uüë§(üéâ)

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Pareto Improvement
The move from a policy y to an alternative policy x is a Pareto improvement if x Pareto dominates y.

Such a policy change should reasonably be seen as unambiguously good
Another perspective is that no-one would veto a pareto improvement

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Pareto Efficiency
An outcome is Pareto Efficient (Optimal) if no other outcome Pareto dominates it.
An outcome is Pareto Infficient if at least one other outcome Pareto dominates it.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Ranking the Planting Payoffs
Compare (4,3,3) to (1,2,2)

Which one is Pareto dominating?

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Ranking the Planting Payoffs
Now compare (4,3,3) to (3,4,3) or (3,3,4)

Which one is Pareto dominating?

Is the rollback equilibrium outcome a Pareto efficient one?

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: Discussion: Efficiency vs other social comparisons
text:
Discussion: Efficiency vs other social comparisons


How useful is Pareto Efficiency in the real world?
How else could we group outcomes?
We might address this later in the class with what is known as Cooperative Game Theory
